net.sf.mmm.search.engine.base

Class AbstractSearchResultPage

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.sf.mmm.search.engine.base.AbstractSearchResultPage
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Iterable<SearchHit>, SearchResultPage
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    SearchResultPageImpl

    public abstract class AbstractSearchResultPage
extends Object
implements SearchResultPage
    This is the abstract base implementation of the SearchResultPage interface.
    Author:
    Joerg Hohwiller (hohwille at users.sourceforge.net)

                                int totalHits,
                                int hitPerPage,
                                int pageNumber)
        The constructor.
        Parameters:
        searchQuery - is the query that caused this page.
        totalHits - is the total number of hits.
        hitPerPage - is the number of hits per page.
        pageNumber - is the index of this page.

    • Method Detail

      • getHitsPerPage

        public int getHitsPerPage()
        This method gets the number of hits per page. The last page may have less hits than this value.
        Specified by:

      • getPageCount

        public int getPageCount()
        This method gets the number of pages used to split the total hits. An empty search result will have one empty page.
        Specified by:
        getPageCount in interface SearchResultPage
        Returns:
        the number of pages.

      • getPageIndex

        public int getPageIndex()
        This method gets the index of the page represented by this search result, where 0 is the first page and SearchResultPage.getPageCount() - 1 is the last page.
        Specified by:
        getPageIndex in interface SearchResultPage
        Returns:
        the index of the page represented by this result.

      • getHitStartNumber

        public int getHitStartNumber()
        This method gets the absolute number of the first hit of this page. This is the same as: 
         SearchResultPage.getPageIndex() * SearchResultPage.getHitsPerPage() + 1
        Specified by:
        getHitStartNumber in interface SearchResultPage
        Returns:
        the number of the first hit of this page.

      • getHitEndNumber

        public int getHitEndNumber()
        This method gets the absolute number of the last hit of this page. This is the same as: 
         SearchResultPage.getHitStartNumber() + SearchResultPage.getPageHitCount()
        Specified by:
        getHitEndNumber in interface SearchResultPage
        Returns:
        the number of the last hit of this page.

      • getPagingStartIndex

        public int getPagingStartIndex(int pagingRange)
        This method gets the page-index of the start page when a number (pagingRange*2)+1 links should be rendered for paging. The pagingRange actually specifies the number of links forward and backwards.
        The number of result-pages is potentially NOT limited. To avoid that your GUI layout gets broken by too many paging links, you can use this method to render a fixed number of paging links.
        E.g. assume pagingCount is 2 and you would have a page-count of e.g. 10. Then you would render links for visiting the pages from 0 to 4 if your page-index is 0,1 , or 2. For a page-index of 3, you would render the links from 1 to 5 and so on.
        The calculation is performed per call so avoid multiple calls of this method if possible.
        Specified by:
        getPagingStartIndex in interface SearchResultPage
        Parameters:
        pagingRange - the number of paging links forward and backwards.
        Returns:
        the page-index to start paging with.
        See Also:
        SearchResultPage.getPagingEndIndex(int)

      • getPagingEndIndex

        public int getPagingEndIndex(int pagingRange)
        This method gets the page-index of the end page when a number (pagingRange*2)+1 links should be rendered for paging. The pagingRange actually specifies the number of links forward and backwards.
        The number of result-pages is potentially NOT limited. To avoid that your GUI layout gets broken by too many paging links, you can use this method to render a fixed number of paging links.
        E.g. assume pagingCount is 2 and you would have a page-count of e.g. 10. Then you would render links for visiting the pages from 5 to 9 if your page-index is 7,8 , or 9. For a page-index of 6, you would render the links from 4 to 8 and so on.
        The calculation is performed per call so avoid multiple calls of this method if possible.
        Specified by:
        getPagingEndIndex in interface SearchResultPage
        Parameters:
        pagingRange - the number of paging links forward and backwards.
        Returns:
        the page-index to end paging with.
        See Also:
        SearchResultPage.getPagingStartIndex(int)
